Main Page | Related Pages

Specification for ISO ProcessData XML files (device description)

General notes

  • This version of proc2iso is designed to work with TCs. It parses a device description given in xml format and generates a C++-bytestream for the upload to the TC and a C++-header file
    with the necessary declarations for the correct constructors (see tutorials 2_0 to 2_6).

Usage in your own project

  • First, include the necessary header in your main-file
  • That could be like that: 
    #include "../2_0_LocalReadDataStdIso/devicedescription/DeviceDescription.xml-func.h"
  • That header includes the bytestream generated from proc2iso and all process data declarations.
  • To make that device description known in the TC client it has to be stored in a map (with possibly more and other device descriptions) 
    bool b_registerSuccess = getIProcessInstance().getDevPropertyHandlerInstance().registerDevicePool(&c_myIdent, deviceDescription_de,
                         ui32_arrayLength_de, true);
  • If the device pool was registered successfully the function returns true. The ending of deviceDescription_xx and ui32_arrayLength_xx depends on the language
    code in the localizationlabel of the device description and has to be hand customized.

General structure of the XML-file

First of all some general rules for the structure of a device description.
  • All elements of one device must be included in one XML-file.
  • Per XML-file only one <device> XML-element is allowed. It is the root element and includes all other XML-elements.
    Have a look at a little codesnippet to show that root element: 
    <device designator="Device1" software_version="0.1" workingset_mastername="Ma00a1900ffe0001b" serialnumber="WXYZ999" structure_label="STRUCT4"
        localization_label="de50015A56FF" device_program_name="myDevice">
[...]
</device>
  • Every XML-element which could contain nested elements has to be "closed" with a closing tag </device>
A further code example shows how XML-elements have to be nested in the root element: 
<device designator="Device1" software_version="0.1" workingset_mastername="Ma00a1900ffe0001b" serialnumber="WXYZ999" structure_label="STRUCT4"
        localization_label="de50015A56FF" device_program_name="myDevice">
  <deviceelement designator="DeviceElement1" element_type="device" element_number="2" parent_name="Device1">
    <deviceprocessdata designator="On Off" ddi="0x008D" properties="defaultset" trigger_methods="timeinterval" proc_program_name="myOnoff"
                       cumulative_value="false">
      <deviceprocessdatacombination ddi="0x008D" command_type="exact" is_setpoint="true"/>
      <devicedinprocessdata lis="0" wert_inst="0x1" />
    </deviceprocessdata>
  </deviceelement>
</device>
Note that XML-elements which don't contain any nested element are closed that way: <devicedinprocessdata [...] />.

Naming-Conventions for < TAG attribute =' value ' >

  • All elements are named according to ISO 11783. A further XML-element was added to enable processdata elements with more than one DDI (e.g. with min and max values). It is called deviceprocessdatacombination.
    Example: processdata Bale Size: there are five different defined DDI's for the bale size. Sometimes it is necessary to measure several values from one processdata.
  • Tags are written WITHOUT underscores or spaces (for example "<deviceprocessdata>").
  • Attributes are written only WITH underscores (for example "command_type=").
  • Values are written WITHOUT underscores or spaces, the name of the XML-element is an exception (for example "defaultset").

Using objects: Allowed object nesting

The following table shows which objects may be included into which other.
Name of XML-Tag Allowed inclusion of objects of following types
device DeviceElement | DeviceValuePresentation
deviceelement DeviceProcessData | DeviceProperty
deviceprocessdata DeviceDinProcessData | DeviceProcessDataCombination
deviceproperty none
devicedinprocessdata none
deviceprocessdatacombination none
devicevaluepresentation none

Reference for correct attribute names

Next table gives a review of all available attributes with value range.
attribute name attribute type
designatorChose a name which is descriptive for the represented element, max. 32 chars
software_versionDevice software version, max. 32 chars
workingset_masternameDouble Integer, Special treatment of Working Set Master NAME
serialnumberDevice Serial Number, max. 32 chars
structure_labelLabel given by Device to identify Device Description Structure, max. 7 chars
localization_labelLabel given by Device to identify Device Description Localization (Byte 1 to 6 defined by the Language Command PGN
(see ISO 11873-7), Byte 7 is reserved and set to 0xFF)
element_typeDevice Element Types or directly 1..7
element_numberInteger, 0...4095
parent_nameName of parent DeviceElementObject or DeviceObject to establish a hierarchical of device elements
ddiInteger, 0...65535
propertiesInteger, 1 or 2
trigger_methodsTrigger methods
device_value_presentation_nameIs used, if a DeviceValuePresentationObject is referenced. If nothing is referenced leave it out.
property_valueSigned Integer, -231...(231-1)
lisUsing DIN
wert_instUsing DIN
zaehl_numUsing DIN
offsetSigned Integer, -231...(231-1)
scaleFloat, 0.000000001...100000000.0
number_of_decimalsByte, 0...7
unit_designatorString, max. 32 chars
self_configurable_address1 Bit, 0 or 1, default: 0
industry_group3 Bit, 0...8, default: 2
function8 Bit, 0...255, default: 25
wanted_saInteger, default: 128
function_instance5 Bit, 0...32, default: 0
ecu_instance3 Bit, 0...8, default: 0
store_sa_at_eeprom_addressif a source address (sa) was assigned to a self-configurable device, that sa should be assigned too for next powercycle,
default: 0xFFFF
manufacturer_code11 Bit, 0...2048
device_class7 Bit, 0...128
device_class_instance4 Bit, 0...16
ws_identity_number21 Bit, 0...2097152
feature_setFeature set
priorityIs used as a parameter in the processdata contructor and is a priority code of messages with this processdata instance.
It is set to 2 by default.
device_program_nameString, name of the device in the main-file
proc_program_nameString, name of the processdata in the main-file
cumulative_valueCumulative value
command_typeCommand types
is_setpointSet point

Allowed attributes for a XML-element

The following listing shows for every XML-element what attributes are available. If an attribute is required it has to be set to a valid value otherwise the parser interrupts.
If an attribute is not required, it means that is will be set to a default value.
XML-element Name of attribute Required
device designator yes
software_version yes
workingset_mastername yes, or splitted in 9 parts see the following
self_configurable_address no (use if workingset_mastername is left out)
industry_group no (use if workingset_mastername is left out)
function no (use if workingset_mastername is left out)
function_instance no (use if workingset_mastername is left out)
ecu_instance no (use if workingset_mastername is left out)
manufacturer_code yes (use if workingset_mastername is left out)
device_class yes (use if workingset_mastername is left out)
device_class_instance yes (use if workingset_mastername is left out)
ws_identity_number yes (use if workingset_mastername is left out)
serialnumber yes
structure_label yes
localization_label yes
device_program_name yes
wanted_sa no
store_sa_at_eeprom_address no
deviceelement designator no
element_type yes
element_number no
parent_name yes
deviceprocessdata designator yes, restricted to 30 chars
ddi yes
properties no
trigger_methods no
proc_program_name yes
cumulative_value no
priority no
device_value_presentation_name no
devicepropertydesignator no
ddi yes
property_value yes
device_value_presentation_name no
devicedinprocessdata lis no
wert_inst no
zaehl_num no
deviceprocessdatacombination ddi yes
command_type no
is_setpoint yes
devicevaluepresentation designator yes
offset yes
scale yes
number_of_decimals yes
unit_designator no

Device Element Types

If you want to specify what type a device element is, the attribute value has a range of 1...7 (see ISO 11873-10 Annex A.3), alternatively you can use one of the following 7 device element type constants:

Name of device element type
(1) device
(2) function
(3) bin
(4) section
(5) unit
(6) connector
(7) navigationreference

Trigger methods

If you want to specify the trigger method for a device process data, the attribute value has a range of 0...31 (see ISO 11873-10 Annex A.4), alternatively you can use one of the following 5 trigger method constants:

Name of trigger method
(1) timeinterval
(2) distanceinterval
(4) threshold limits
(8) onchange
(16) counter

Feature Set

Commonly, there are several processdata value for measurement, but if the user is sure that there is only one processdata value for measuring, he can decide to chose between the following
value of feature_set
Standard (recommended) just leave that attribute out
SimpleMeasureonly one value will be measured (the last, although several process data values are available)
SimpleSetpointonly one value will be set point (the last, although several process data values are available)
SimpleSetpointSimpleMeasureonly one value will be measured and set point (the last, although there are more process data values)

Using DIN

To ensure the support to corresponding DIN standard, there are a further XML-element and some additional attributes which are only used for DIN. If they are not given they will be set to default values. These values are necessary for the constructor built. Have a look at the following codesnippet: 
<deviceprocessdata designator="Fan Speed" ddi="0xE109" properties="defaultset" trigger_methods="timeinterval" proc_program_name="fanSpeed"
 cumulative_value="false">
  <devicedinprocessdata lis="0" wert_inst="2" zaehl_num= "0xff"/>
</deviceprocessdata>
This XML-element is nested in the deviceprocessdata element.
DIN attributes
lis identifierlist, default: 0
wert_inst wert stands for the valuegroup and inst for the instance
zaehl_num is comparable with the working width (0xFF is the default and means the whole working width)
For further information to DIN elements see DIN 9684-1.

Cumulative value

  • Cumulative values are values like area, distance or time. The value of the measure data sets is updated on master value update dependent on the value increment since the last master value update.
  • If a remote member resets his data set copy, datas of other members aren't changed
  • Non-cumulative values like speed, state, rpm are not updated by increment. They are set directly.
    Truth values

Command types and set point

Command types
exact
default
min
max

Possible values of is_setpoint: Truth values

  • The different command types and setpoint are working together.
  • If is_setpoint is false, all measurements are exact.
  • If is_setpoint is true, all measurements are set point.

"About the designator of a DeviceProcessData element"

Using a processdata element with a DDI group needs some naming convention. For every deviceprocessdatacombination the command_type and if measurement or not attribute is required. So the designator of the deviceprocessdata is extended with '_x'. x stands for:

extensionCommand types
0 exact setpoint
1 default (is always setpoint)
2 min setpoint
3 max setpoint
4 exact measurement
- not used
6 min measurement
7 max measurement

E.g. CylinderPressure_4 means a exact measurement value DDI. For those two additional characters the length of the deviceprocessdata designator is restricted to 30 characters.

Special treatment of Working Set Master NAME

  • The Working Set Master NAME is also called isoname. It consists of nine parts with different information.
  • First possibility is to specify the working set master name as a whole double integer with 8 byte. It has to start with the character L (for least significant bit) or M (most significant bit).
  • That is necessary because of different storage methods (endianess).
The workingset master name looks like that: 
<device [...] workingset_mastername="Ma00a1900ffe0001b" [...]>

The other possibility is to specify every single part of the workingset master name: 
<device [...] self_configurable_address="false" industry_group="2" device_class_instance="0" device_class="1" function="25" function_instance="0"
 ecu_instance="0" manufacturer_code="0x17" ws_identity_number="0x1BB000" [...]/>
If self_configurable_address, industry_group, function, function_instance and ecu_instance are not given they will be set to default values. Value ranges are defined in section Reference for correct attribute names.

Truth values

Truth values
true/yes
false/no
